Fig. 1 Sources of synthesis gas for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 FTS is a balancing act controlled by the localized electron donating capability of the active surface. “X2” and “L” simply denote localized carbon hybridization as sp3 and sp2 respectivelly. Selectivity toward those products increased because of these localized environments. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Commercial reactors for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. (a) Exxon and (b) Sasol slurry bubble column reactors, (c) multitubular trickle bed reactor, (d) circulating fluidized-bed reactor, and (e) fixed fluidized-bed reactor [299]. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Different forms of aluminum used as structured materials for FTS, including (left) knitted wire [325] and (middle) foam [325]; and (right) Velocys microchannel FTS reactor core [317,318](Copyright, Velocys, 2012). Graphical abstract This review is divided into three main sections. The first section of this overview examines in detail recent techno-economic analyses on the utilization of biomass as a source of syngas for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS). FTS is a highly localized industry, and depends on the sources of syngas available, the products desired, and the demand for co- production of electricity. Where coal or natural gas coexist in the region where biomass is available, economics may favor producing or blending syngas from multiple resources, making biomass-to-liquids a highly complex scenario. Land use management is essential for sustainable biomass production, if used as the carbon source for FTS. The second section discusses FTS mechanisms, reactions and catalysts. Supposing the catalyst surface energy favors CO hydrogenation to FTS products, the sweet spot of FTS, selectivity will depend on the degree of back- donation from the metal. The degree of electron back-donation from the catalyst surface to both adsorbed CO and vinylic intermediates in part controls the FT synthesis product distribution. When the back-donation is sufficient, chain growth favors longer chained linear hydrocarbons (paraffins, alpha olefins, linear alcohols) suitable for upgrading to diesel, jet fuels, lubricants, and waxes. When back-donation is less significant, monomethyl branched hydrocarbons, internal olefins, and oxygenates (esters, acids and ketones) are elevated. Lastly, active supports are discussed for increasing the termination rate to oxygenates and olefins, as are hybrid catalysts that simultaneously carry out FTS and upgrading, often through secondary reactions. The last section provides an overview of the commercial scale reactor designs including the fixed bed, fluidized bed, and slurry bubble column reactor currently used in the FTS process. Economically, FTS is favored at larger scales; however, new compact reactor designs are coming into play aimed at monetizing highly localized (e.g. biomass) and stranded resources (e.g. natural gas). These types of reactors, involving microchannel and heat exchanger designs, must be highly efficient at managing heat, cost-effective, and mobile in order to exploit non-traditional sources of syngas. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch Biomass-to-Liquids Coal-to-Liquids Gas-to-Liquids Mechanism Cobalt catalyst Iron catalyst 1 Introduction This manuscript is a collaborative work from researchers of different backgrounds, who had the honor to work alongside Dr. Davis in some capacity or another. Dr. Davis was a trailblazer, mentor, and leader. His work in the catalysis field was remarkable, spanning over 60 years and resulting in over 800 publications, and around 20,000 citations to date. His work highly contributed to Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, liquefaction, hydrotreating, alcohol conversion, isomerization, aromatization, hydrogen production and purification, and many other industrial fields. Like his predecessor Dr. Emmett, Dr. Davis used radio labeled and non-radio labeled isotopes to further understand the mechanistic routes of these extremely complicated reaction networks. In the final stage of his career, Dr. Davis was working on projects that utilized syngas from combined feedstocks, such as biomass and coal. Therefore, we decided to provide a brief overview of this area with a focus on findings from CAER during Dr. Davis’ tenure. 2 Summary of techno-economic analyses The comparison among different studies is complex, as the competitiveness of Biomass-to-Liquids (BtL) or combined processes (e.g. CBtL, GBtL) depends not only on crude oil pricing, but also on local government policy for green-house gas (GHG) reduction, land management, and the particular feedstocks utilized. As this is a general overview, this section will only focus on the fundamental gasification routes paired with discussions on economics and viability. 2.1 Biomass-to-Liquids process Gas-to-Liquids (GtL) and Coal-to-Liquids (CtL) are well-established technologies for the production of synthetic fuels (e.g., commercial plants of Shell and Sasol) [1]. In contrast, few plants at the pilot and demonstration scales are available worldwide for BtL. If syngas produced from coal were replaced by renewable biomass, then a net reduction in emissions would result. Any CO2 involved in the BtL process is assumed to be recycled by photosynthesis, whereas it takes 300 million years to make coal from plant matter. Moreover, even today, the bulk of the biomaterials are left to rot or are burned in fires, contributing to increases in carbon dioxide levels. Thus, by using biorenewable materials to produce fuels or chemicals, the net amount of CO2 released would be less than what would be produced using fossil-based resources alone. Thus, if 20% of the total liquid fuels were produced from biomass, then a reduction in CO2 emissions of 15% could potentially be achieved [2]. The BtL process (Fig. 1 ) has four basic steps: (1) transportation, storage, handling and pretreatment of the biomass; (2) gasification to syngas (mixture of CO and H2) followed by gas cleaning/conditioning; (3) Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS); and (4) upgrading of FTS liquids to high quality fuels. The main obstacle impeding commercialization is lack of competitiveness in today’s energy market because of (1) a complicated and diverse biomass supply, (2) expensive biomass transportation and feed preparation (e.g., torrefaction) costs, and (3) high plant capital costs [1,3–7]. Different biomass feedstocks can be used in BtL, including dry residues such as straw, energy crops (e.g., short- rotation or herbaceous wood, sugar, oil seed, miscanthus grass, switchgrass), wood materials from forestry operations, municipal/industrial/agricultural organic waste, and algae [8]. Depending on the origin, biomass feedstocks have different physico-chemical properties (e.g., moisture, ash content, particle size, energy density and toxicity) (Table 1 ) [5,9–16]. These differences influence transport, pretreatment, gasification, and cleaning/conditioning steps [7–9]. Biomass cost is coupled with several factors such as: resource and land availability, supply chain, and processing costs, and require vastly different CapEx costs [6,17–19]. Availability of abundant low cost biomass is the main challenge for achieving economic competitiveness [20]. This does not rule out that locally available biomass can be ideally processed as feedstock in a small-scale bio-refinery; rather, very high investment costs must be considered for this configuration, because large-scale investments are essential for achieving high returns [6]. A reason for these costs lie in the complexities in understanding specific concentrations of biomass for land management [21–29]. These types of assessments are of great importance but lie outside the scope of this review, as focus will remain on types of biomass specifically. High transportation costs result from decentralized production and the lower energy density of biomass relative to coal and natural gas (NG) [4,30]. Biomass can be transported by road, rail, water or pipeline. Trucking is usually the cheapest and most flexible means of transport when the distance is less than 100 km [1]. Local pre- processing close to the production source can minimize the cost of logistics [31]. This pretreatment before gasification is characterized by: drying (decreasing the moisture to 40%), densification (e.g., balling, briquetting or pelletizing) and grinding (reducing the particle size to increase both surface area and heat transfer characteristics) [7]. Torrefaction (heating at 200–300 °C under an inert atmosphere) can be another route to enhance the potential of biomass prior to gasification. This results in loss in moisture, hydrogen and oxygenated species, producing a “coal-like” material [8]. Torrefied biomass contains around 70% and 90% of its initial weight and energy, respectively [32], whereas moisture level varies from 1 to 6% [31]. The type of gasifier (fixed bed, fluidized, entrained flow, rotary kiln or plasma), its performance as well as the produced syngas (composition and calorific value) are influenced by feedstock properties [7,9,35]. Particle size range and moisture content are two of the main parameters considered in the choice of the gasifier. Generally, when water content in the biomass is less than 15% (e.g., wood or herbaceous biomass), an entrained flow reactor as well as all fixed-bed gasifiers (updraft, downdraft and cross-draft) can be used, while high-moisture biomass (up to 60% wet basis - e.g., oil palm empty fruit bunch) requires an updraft fixed-bed or a fluidized reactor [8]. Moreover, biomass with either light treatment or no pretreatment can be supplied to a rotary kiln or plasma reactor [36]. Particles sizes usually range from 0.15 mm to 51 mm [8]. Fixed bed reactors are less sensitive (< 51 mm) than fluidized bed reactors (< 6 mm) or entrained flow gasifiers (<0.15 mm) [37]. The best gasifier in terms of syngas quality is the plasma reactor, however lower tar content can be obtained with an entrained flow gasifier than fluidized or fixed bed reactors. More details regarding types of gasifiers, as well as their advantages/limitations, can be found in previous reviews available in the literature [36,37]. The main capital costs of BtL are gasification and syngas clean-up [10]. Gasification accounts for up to 39% of costs for an oxygen-steam fluidized bed reactor [38]. Capital costs were found to be 15% for indirectly-heated gasifiers and 27% for directly-heated gasifiers, whereas the cleanup step accounted for about 20–26% of the total cost [39]. Syngas cleaning for FTS applications are severe (H2S/COS < 0.01 μLL−1, NH3/HCN < 0.02 μLL−1, alkali and halides < 0.01 μLL−1) [8]. Optimization of gasification process conditions (e.g., temperature), as well as development of FTS catalysts more resistant to contaminants, like sulfur, greatly impact the cost analysis. Due to the great diversity in biomass and depending on the production side steam, biomass-derived syngas may have a H2/CO ratio in the range of 0.5–1.0, allowing both cobalt and iron-based catalysts to be used [40,41]. Cobalt has higher productivity and conversion, but upstream water-gas shift (WGS) or steam oxidation on the production side, will be required to boost the H2/CO ratio. Iron possesses intrinsic WGS activity, so FTS and WGS can be carried out in a single reactor [40]. Yet, with the diversity in biomass, iron catalysts may be preferred for the downstream FT step, as they are more resistant to sulfur contaminants in syngas. Regarding gasifier design, steam oxidation is typically more economically viable at smaller scales [41]. Based upon the literature, BtL has an efficiency that typically ranges between 28 and 40% for the conversion of raw materials to end products [1,6,11,18,19,42,43]. In general, oxy-steam and air-blown fixed bed gasifiers have efficiencies in the range of 75–81%, while the syngas to liquid fuel efficiency (diesel and wax) for a cobalt catalyst is in the range of 35–50% [6,11]. The development of high yield catalysts, efficient FTS reactors with high heat transfer rates, improved technologies for O2 generation consumed to produce syngas, syngas purification and CO2 separation, are all fundamentally important for improving the overall BtL efficiency [6]. Obviously, there are limitations to these studies, as any model must draw upon certain assumptions. Logistical evaluations, which include detailed realistic economic studies, are typically paid for and conducted by companies, where little outside information is provided. Furthermore, utilizing mobile FTS with compact reactors at the source of the biomass will have a different result compared to operations whereby the biomass must be conveyed to large scale FTS facilities by barges or diesel-powered land vehicles [44]. These considerations, like the concentration of vegetation assessment, are too specific, and outside the scope of this review. Many techno-economic analyses (TEA) have been carried out for BtL [45–49], and fuel costs are in the range of 0.4$/l to 1.39$/l. Jin et al. [46] suggested that production of liquid fuel could compete with petroleum only if low cost biomass is coupled with a low cost in electrical supply energy [46]. Swanson et al. [48] have pointed out that liquid fuel costs could be lowest when coupled with high temperature gasification (∼1300 °C) to yield the highest syngas conversion from biomaterials. Yet, syngas generation still dominates the economic value of the end products, as a sensitivity analysis revealed a significant effect of capital and biomass costs on product value [48]. Thus, TEA studies indicate that BtL is still not competitive with conventional refineries, since the biofuel production costs are 8% higher than current market prices [1]. An economic evaluation reported that BtL concepts only become economically viable if the crude oil price is higher than $80 per bbl and only if the biomass feedstock price is lower than $120 per ton [1]. Moreover, BtL requires relatively high product selling prices to be economically viable. However, in certain locations of the world, achieving high product sales prices does not require high oil prices. The US renewable identification number (RIN) credits available for the highest reduction in carbon intensity (>60%) can account for $2-3/gallon ($84-126/bbl) credits, while the same fuels under California’s low carbon fuel standard can qualify for a further $1.50-2.00/gallon credit. Thus, BtL product sales prices can be as high as $7.00–8.00/gallon today. Issues will remain, as these are statutory credits, and therefore could be rescinded at any time, though this possibility is unlikely. In many parts of Europe, carbon taxes exist, and there are often very significant “tipping fees” for MSW (municipal solid waste) landfilling. In certain cases, revenue from these tipping fees can be significantly higher than those from product fuel sales. Enerkem has an existing commercial MSW gasification to methanol/ethanol plant in Edmonton, Alberta, while Fulcrum Bioenergy is currently constructing a ca. 850 BPD plant based on MSW gasification to FT products in Nevada using a TRI gasifier, and Red Rock Biofuels is currently constructing a ca. 1000 BPD plant based on wood waste gasification to FT products in southeastern Oregon using a TCG Global gasifier. Finally, in the absence of either the credits or carbon taxes, a strategy being considered to make BtL more competitive is to combine biomass feedstock with coal (CBtL) or natural gas (GBtL) [3–5,10,50–53]. 2.2 CBtL technologies CBtL allows the possibility of balancing economic and environmental factors in terms of fuel price and GHG emissions, combining the advantage of both CtL and BtL. CtL can generate fuels at lower costs ($50/bbl), but GHG emissions are high (205 kg CO2,eq/GJ), whereas BtL results in zero or even net-negative GHG emissions if CO2 capture technology is considered but at a higher fuel price ($127/bbl) [30]. Thus, assuming the feedstock is comprised of 43% biomass, GHG emissions for CBtL are 120 kg CO2,eq/GJ, while production costs are $93/bbl [30]. Other studies show that when 8% by weight of biomass (switchgrass) is co-fed with coal, CBtL with CO2 sequestration can produce economically competitive fuels when crude oil is above 93$/bbl; they have 20% lower GHG emissions than petroleum-derived diesel. Co-gasification of 15% and 30% biomass results in emission reductions of 33% and 63%, respectively [52]. Generally economic benefits can be realized when the production capacity is higher than 1 million tons/yr for CtL and 0.8–1.59 million tons/yr for BtL[30]. However, BtL is hindered by limited biomass availability as a large area of land is needed, which affects the maximum plant size limiting the economy of scale [52]. The combination of BtL and CtL allows the CBtL process to inherit the large scale economy of CtL, so it suffers less from this limitation compared to BtL alone [30]. For example, the capacity of CBtL can be 30,000 bbd when 30% of biomass (switchgrass) is co-fed compared to 50,000 bbd for CtL or 5000 bbd BtL alone [52]. This is because the biomass supply rate is limited to 4000 dry tons per day. This is the maximum value assuming that a regional site which can support collection would have a radius of 30 to 50 miles supposing that a delivery truck arrives every 10 min [52]. Similarly to BtL and CtL, a significant debit for CBtL processes is the generally very low H2/CO ratio of syngas. For both methanol and FT, increasing the H2/CO ratio to the required range of about 2 entails conversion of 30–60% of the syngas CO (which is the desired component) to CO2. The coal or biomass gasifier is by far the most expensive unit in these plants, and it is plainly economically problematic to lose a large fraction of potential feed for conversion to products. Perhaps a more economically viable combination would be CBtL with supplemental hydrogen addition produced by electrolysis using (very low cost) renewable electricity. 2.3 GBtL technologies TEA studies for GBtL are limited [3,51,53]. Co-processing NG with biomass has advantages because of the higher NG conversion efficiency, lower capital costs and richer hydrogen content in the feedstock [3]. Increasing the NG/biomass ratio decreases investment and operational costs. When the NG blending ratio is less than 50%, the H2/CO ratio of the syngas produced is less than the stoichiometric value for FTS, requiring WGS [3,40]. When the NG blending ratio is higher than 50%, such that the H2/CO ratio is higher than the stoichiometric value needed for FTS, pressure swing adsorption (PSA) may be used to remove the portion of hydrogen not needed [3]. Environmental sustainability needs must also be addressed. GHG emissions of GBtL increase by increasing the NG co-fed to the biomass. The optimal NG blending ratio must be calculated by considering both economic and environmental factors. GBtL can readily include 28% NG and still meet the GHG threshold reduction target to be classified as an advanced biofuel as defined by the US Environmental Protection Agency [3]. 2.4 PtL technologies Recently, an alternative route to produce renewable jet-fuels is the Power-to-Liquids process (PtL) [54]. The concept of PtL is storing energy from intermittent renewable energy and producing carbon-neutral fuels from CO2 emissions. The hydrogen, produced in an electrolyzer, and CO2 are then directly or indirectly converted to fuels by FTS or the methanol route. The Sunfire PtL Plant (i.e., featuring a solid oxide electrolyte, direct air capture, and FTS) [55] and Soletair [56] are applications of this technology. Vázquez et al. [56] reported that PtL has a carbon efficiency close to 94% and an overall energy efficiency of 47%, while efficiencies up to 63% could be realized in a PtL process with high-temperature electrolysis if concentrated CO2 were obtained from renewable point sources [57]. PtL is relatively new, so limited TEA studies are available [58,59]. TEA shows that the process is still not competitive for the production of fuels or chemicals [58]. Process optimization (e.g., innovative processes for CO2 extraction from air, higher efficiency from the electrolyzer) and dynamic operation studies are required to improve plant flexibility because of the daily, weekly or seasonal fluctuations in renewable energy (e.g., the solar radiation intensity, wind speed) [56]. The main requirement for large-scale implementation is a reduction in cost for the production of hydrogen from water electrolysis as powered by solar and/or wind energy [58]. PtL can also be combined with BtL to boost the production of carbon neutral fuels [60,61]. In this case, the carbon efficiency of conventional BtL can increase from 38% to 90% by adding hydrogen produced in a renewable manner. As such, WGS is avoided, while reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) is introduced to convert CO2 to CO. This means that the amount of fuel can be increased by a factor of 2.4 with the same amount of biomass, while the cost of biofuel produced with PBtL is 30% less compared to BtL [61]. 2.5 XtL direction There are several market analysis groups reporting analysis of specialty markets on a regular basis, some of which were covered in this review. Those studies provide qualitative and quantitative results from end-users regarding manufacturing processes involving the conversion of various feedstocks to high-value specialty products via FT synthesis, including such products as lube oils, alpha olefins, food grade wax, etc. in addition to middle-distillates. However, demands in FT products may continue to shift as the prices of oil and gas change; moreover, the need for LNG may draw the attention away from CtL, GtL, BtL and XtL ( Fig. 1 ). As a whole, CtL and GtL would appear to be favored by the very low current coal and natural gas prices, as well as the abundant number of demonstrated/commercialized technologies available for these processes [1]. However, each time in the past that it appeared large-scale development of either/both was imminent, cyclical crude price collapses rendered most proposed plants uneconomical. This happened despite the claim on more than one occasion that "it's different this time". In the late 70’s/early 80’s, around 2007–2008, and again 2011–2012, claims were made that prices would be high forever. There were many claims that $100/bbl was the new floor, and in 2008 there were predictions that it would soon go to $200/bbl. It went to $35/bbl instead, a reoccurrence trend post WW2 [63,64]. These repeated cycles of crude price boom and bust have certainly increased the perception of economic risk involved in contemplating plants requiring hundreds of millions to multibillion-dollar capital expenditures. BtL development has been hampered by the lack of well demonstrated commercialized biomass gasification technologies. Although there are several BtL plants in construction today and the outlook may change for the better if they are able to operate as designed [6,8]. Clearly the current low carbon/CO2 policies and subsidies make BtL considerably more attractive. Yet, CtL and BtL are further challenged by the need to produce additional H2 to meet the requirements of downstream FTS operations as discussed above. As previously described, gasification and clean-up comprise the majority of the total plant costs for BtL and CtL, so every mole of CO produced is extremely costly. But, conventional processes then proceed to consume 30–45% of the valuable CO to produce H2 (and CO2) by water-gas- shift. This issue is also observed in PtL, where it is currently limited by the developmental status of hydrogen production. An economical source of additional H2 from outside the plant, for example by Power- to-Gas or natural gas reforming, would make such plants a lot much more attractive. Going from CO2 and H2 directly to products is well demonstrated for methanation, but problematic for FTS or methanol synthesis. In the latter processes, overall CO2 conversion is low, as are the selectivities to the desired products. In addition, a significant fraction of the H2 feed is consumed by reaction with oxygen from the CO2, producing water (which is the starting material for H2 production by electrolysis). H2 and CO2 can be converted to CO and H2O, for example by the reverse water-gas-shift reaction, followed by conventional FT or methanol synthesis. Even if high conversion and selectivity to the desidered product can be obtained, the additional processing steps add considerable capital costs, and consume about 1/3 of the H2 required, again simply producing water. Granted, the production of H2 by alkaline or PEM electrolyzers and its use in the direct or indirect CO2 hydrogenation is less than desiderable given the high H2 usage required for oxygen removal/water production. Thus, a more promising solution is the co-electrolysis of CO2 and H2O to produce syngas directly, followed by conventional FT or methanol synthesis. But such co-electrolysis technologies are only now entering or are at pilot plant scale operations, and their widespread commercial availability is at least several years away at best [62]. Futhermore, costs are very high (4-6 times that of alakine electrolyzers), and commercial lifetime (activation/degradation) is uncertain. 3 Fischer Tropsch Synthesis In FTS, syngas (CO and H2) is catalytically converted into a spectrum of hydrocarbon chains, including a fraction of oxygenates Eq. (1)–(3). WGS also may occur depending on the catalyst Eq. (4): (1) F T S : n C O + 2 n + 1 H 2 → C n H 2 n + 2 + n H 2 O (2) n C O + 2 n H 2 → C n H 2 n + n H 2 O (3) n C O + 2 n H 2 → C n H 2 n + 2 O + n - 1 H 2 O (4) W G S : C O + H 2 O ↔ C O 2 + H 2 The four main metals considered for FTS are iron, cobalt, ruthenium, and nickel. Ruthenium, though the most active, is impractical due to its high cost and low abundance [65]. Nickel, though inexpensive, is plagued by coking and typically considered a methanation catalyst [66,67]. Thus, cobalt and iron are the essential active industrial metals for FTS. The cost of iron-based FT catalyst is estimated at $10-40 per pound, whereas cobalt- based FT catalyst can cost $60-100 per pound, and is more susceptible to the marketplace due to increasing demands in aerospace and batteries. Each FT catalyst developed to date has its own yield structure [68]. Cobalt-based catalyst produces more water, and water clean-up is required, whereas iron-based catalyst, active for WGS, produces significant CO2 (which can be sent to a shift reactor if a hydrogen source is available). Iron catalyst can be used in a wider variety of feedstocks compared to cobalt catalyst; however, economics remains the driving force and finding the cheapest available feedstock is imperative. Another advantage for iron, spent Co catalysts must be reclaimed whereas Fe catalyst can be landfilled (if within acceptable environmental standards for copper). In general, though, as previously discussed, iron is commonly paired with CtL and BtL when low H2/CO syngas is available [69]. Cobalt is preferred with GtL, as it requires a higher H2/CO ratio (close to 2) to be most effective [69]. 3.1 Catalysts Structural and chemical promoters are usually added to iron-based catalysts. Binders such as silica are usually added to improve the structural rigidity of iron catalysts [70–73]. Alkali metals are electronic promoters that facilitate carburization, increase FTS activity, maintain stability, and improve the selectivity to high molecular weight hydrocarbons [74–80]. There are a number of studies that have been done for the promotion of iron with various metals, mainly for the sake of tuning, which will be discussed in more detail [77,80–89]. Promoters such as copper are added in part to facilitate the reduction of iron oxides [90–92]. Because cobalt is expensive, to increase the number of cobalt atoms exposed at the surface, cobalt nanoparticles are dispersed on carriers such as typical metal oxides [93,94], zeolites [95], carbon materials [96–102], silicon carbide [103], partially reducible oxides (PRO) like manganese [104,105] and ceria [106,107], and various other materials [108–112]. Many of these supports, originally thought to be inert, are now being used to promote a specific selectivity to be discussed. Unlike iron, promoters used for cobalt do not significantly increase the turnover frequency; rather, these metals aid in increasing the % of reduction of cobalt oxides to Co metal [113,114]. Whether these additives promote methanation depends on the nature of the promoter [113,115–117]. Lastly, unlike cobalt and ruthenium, where the metallic surface is deemed active for FTS, several species of iron carbide exhibit FTS activity [118]. 3.2 Mechanism Ninety years have passed since the discovery of FTS [119–123]; however, many details regarding the mechanism remain speculative [107,118,124–148]. Interactions between the active metals and CO or H2 are still being investigated to elucidate specific dissociation pathways, as well as their kinetic effect on hydrocarbon chain-growth [107,124–130,133,135–138,140–143,145–155]. CO may dissociate directly or with the assistance of H2 in a concerted manner [156–167]. Two different mechanistic families have been proposed to explain initiation and chain growth steps during FTS: the carbide mechanism and CO insertion. In carbide mechanisms, first proposed by Fischer and Tropsch [121], CO dissociatively adsorbs to form carbide and surface oxygen [130,131,135,145,146]. Carbide species are partially hydrogenated to CHx intermediates which serve as the chain growth monomer. Termination occurs by desorption of unsaturated intermediates to form olefins or by addition of CH3 species or hydrogen to form paraffins [130,131,135,145,146]. In CO insertion mechanisms [68,142,143,168–172], CO directly inserts into the growing hydrocarbon chain prior to C–O scission [156–167]. Micro-kinetic models, isotope tracer studies, and steady state and transient kinetic investigations lend support to this mechanistic scheme, where C–O scission is the key step [74,105,118,140–142,155,173–221]. Isotopic kinetic experiments were performed by switching from H2/CO to D2/CO while maintaining constant conditions (T, P, space velocity, H2/CO) to obtain a steady state CO conversion. Hydrogen/deuterium experiments performed during FTS have displayed various kinetic rate ratios, but have conclusively displayed an inverse kinetic isotope effect (IKIE) [182,183,190,197,205,222]. Results from isotopic surface partitioning experiments suggest that the H/D isotopic effect is not due to chemisorption [223–226]. Rather, H/D partitioning studies indicate that a nearly uniform (H/D ≅ 0.97) mixture of hydrogen isotopes exists on the active metal surface [223–226]. This nearly uniform partitioning, coupled with the IKIE observed in H-D switching during FTS reaction tests, suggests kinetic limitations in H-bond formation, which agree with the calculated IKIE values [150,205,159,163,165,227–230]. 3.3 Tuning Reactor type and process conditions can alter product selectivity; however, dramatic changes in selectivity are also achieved by adjusting the catalyst formulation. Thus, selectivity is a fingerprint of the catalyst formulation [68]. Desired selectivity is achieved by the capability of the catalyst, under controlled conditions (temperature, pressure, space velocity, H2/CO), to maintain a balance among adsorbed reactants and products [130,135,140,142,144,146,205,217,225,231–237]; this balance depends on tuning the localized electron density at the active catalyst surface, through electronic back donation to the 2π* anti-bonding molecular orbital of CO [129,238–240]. The electron density of the active metal, in turn, can be modified by adding specific promoters [150,241–246]. Although there is debate in the literature [107,124–130,133,135–138,140–143,145–155], one explanation for the diversity in selectivity fingerprints among different catalyst formulations is the involvement of the electronic tuning of a vinylic intermediate. A collection of labeled 14C isotopic studies describe ethylene as a chain initiator of FTS with >99% primary incorporation [154,156,247–255]. Furthermore, ethylene/CO/H2 or propylene/CO/H2 feeds resulted in enhanced higher hydrocarbon production [154,252], which directly corresponded to the amounts of ethylene/propylene incorporated [154,252]. Furthermore, without CO, 10% ethylene/H2 produced products at a higher rate [152]. Simply put, FTS selectivity may rely on the stability of a 2-carbon species [68] which in turn relies on electronic back-donation; if too weak or too strong, only CHX is formed, leading to methanation. Since CO and vinylic intermediates are pi-accepting ligands, both are susceptible to electronic back-donation from the catalyst surface (Fig. 2 ) . The figure displays a Dewar-Chatt-Duncanson model [256–259] describing how localized back-donation from the metal affects how these species interact. If the localized sp2 character is retained, both CO and C2 will be weakly bound to the surface, and the CC bond length observed in IR is remarkably similar to a free CC bond (L). In contrast, if back-donation is strong, carbon takes on more sp3 character, as a metallocyclopropane species. Vibrational observations then reveal that the CC bond weakens to resemble a single bond (X2). Thus, a balance in electron back-donation for FTS is of great importance, and if not held, could lead to inferior catalysts having poor selectivity. In general, and using the figure as a guide, three different major scenarios can be identified [68]: • Route A: weak back- donation. CO is adsorbed molecularly as the scission of CO bond with H* is not kinetically favored. If CO is weakly adsorbed, then the vinylic intermediate species would be in an L- configuration (linear molecule) weakly bound to the surface. Thus, the intermediate is susceptible to hydrogenation reactions and high selectivities to methane and light hydrocarbons are observed. As CO dissociation is difficult, carbon growth from the weakly-bound L configured vinylic intermediate could be through CO insertion [68,142,143,168–172]. Moreover, the carbons of the vinylic intermediate exhibit sp2 hybridization (electrophilic nature) because of the weak back- donation from the metal; consequently, chain growth can occur at either C position, resulting in internal olefins, branched paraffins (i.e., typically monomethyl branched hydrocarbons due to steric factors), and oxygenated materials (e.g., esters, acids, ketone, aldehydes) through a pseudo-hydroformylation series of steps. This configuration has been proposed for un-promoted iron carbide [68]. • Route B: semi-strong back-donation CO adsorbs in an associative manner followed by H-assisted dissociation on the active site. As adsorbed CO is stable, so is the vinylic intermediate, X2- configuration. These species are suitably stabilized on the active surface to favor chain growth solely at the Cx position (Fig. 2), resulting in a fingerprint of primarily linear paraffins and 1-olefins, as observed for cobalt and ruthenium catalysts. Oxygenates do form, but the term “oxygenates” is too general, as virtually only linear alcohols are formed [68]. Potassium-promoted iron catalysts may also be included in this configuration. CO readily dissociates as potassium facilitates back donation [90–92]. However, the selectivity fingerprint is different from cobalt or ruthenium, as H2 is limited. The vinylic intermediate will desorb without hydrogenation resulting in a higher fraction of oxygenates and alkenes [68]. However, the promoter may only modify the local electronic environment, so not all of the FTS sites may benefit from the effect of promoters [68]. The possibility for simultaneous routes occurring on the active catalyst may be possible [68]. • Route C: strong back-donation As CO rapidly dissociates [130,131,135,145,146], the vinylic intermediate (π acceptor) will also easily dissociate, forming a carbidic phase. The X2-configuration, though present, will not possess sufficient stability and will dissociate to an active carbidic phase (Cs), which will convert to methane or inactive graphitic carbon [66,260]. This configuration occurs with nickel. After 13CO was decomposed on the surface of Ni/SiO2, immediately after, H2 and unlabeled CO produced 13CH4/12CH4, and 12CO2, suggesting that methanation involves a Cs intermediate [260]. As previously discussed, the balance maintained among adsorbed species has a dramatic effect on the selectivity fingerprint. Thus, modifications to this balance are strictly correlated to the strength of back donation from the active metal, which is adjusted by promoters (e.g., K, Rb and Cs) [77,79,80,86,261–263]. However, further changes in the fingerprint may be achieved by employing active supports (e.g., CeO2, MnO2 or zeolite) [95,107,106,235,264–275]. Ceria [271,276], a PRO, increases the selectivity to linear alcohols, as observed in Table 2 . Manganese can be used to increase the olefin content [264,267,269,277,278], carbon can be used to slightly increase alcohols and olefins [279,280], and zeolite bifunctionality can be used to increase isomerized products [272,273,281,282]. 3.4 CO2 hydrogenation The hydrogenation of CO2 may proceed through a two-step reaction mechanism [168,283–286], where CO2 is first converted to CO via RWGS, and then CO reacts to form hydrocarbons via FTS. Both cobalt and iron are active for the hydrogenation of CO2 [168,283–285,287–293]. In the case of cobalt-based catalysts, the reaction shifts from FTS toward methanation (CH4, and eventually C2- C4 hydrocarbons, are the dominant products) when CO is replaced by CO2 [168,283,285,290]. Some authors propose different reaction pathways involving CO and CO2 [293]. Others consider that CO and CO2 have the same mechanistic pathway but that the difference lies in the selectivity between CO and CO2 hydrogenation because of a different H/C ratio on the catalyst surface [291] or because of the loss of the “selective inhibition” for methanation when CO is switched to CO2 [285]. Iron catalysts are reported to be more effective than cobalt for the hydrogenation of CO2 to high molecular weight hydrocarbons. This can be attributed either to their intrinsic activity for the RWGS reaction or their ability to directly hydrogenate CO2 [285]. Middle distillates or heavy hydrocarbons can be formed depending on the catalyst formulation (e.g., amount of alkali) [285,292]. CO2 hydrogenation involves CO as an intermediate, and FTS activity is established by carbiding the iron, which is facilitated by the alkali promoter. Some authors have even reported the formation of light paraffins during CO2 hydrogenation on un- promoted iron catalyst [294,295]. The different selectivities during CO and CO2 hydrogenation can be attributed either to a different H/C ratio on the catalyst surface or to the lower stability of the active iron carbide during CO2 hydrogenation [291,292]. In fact, during CO2 hydrogenation, the fraction of Fe3O4 and other oxidized Fe species (FeOx) increases with time due to the oxidation of χ-Fe5C2 species [296,297]. In this scenario, the addition of potassium plays a key role in promoting the stability of the iron carbide site and in decreasing secondary reactions of olefins during CO2 hydrogenation [292]. In conclusion, the conventional iron catalyst can be used for the hydrogenation of CO2 to hydrocarbons; however, the formulation needs to be optimized (e.g., alkali type and loading) in order to achieve the desired selectivity [290]. 4 FT reactor development Optimization of both reactor configuration and process parameters is essential to maximize efficiency and achieve desired product selectivity [298]. In this section, recent developments in FTS reactors are discussed. Since FTS is a highly exothermic reaction, heat management is critical. Excessive reaction temperatures lead to higher methane yield, carbon deposition, and catalyst deactivation [299]. In the early stages, slurry bubble column (SBCR), multi-tubular trickle-bed, circulating fluidized-bed, and fixed fluidized-bed reactors were utilized for FTS (Fig. 3 ), and review articles are available [300–305]. 4.1 Slurry bubble column reactors The development of a low-temperature slurry phase FTS process began in 1938 by Kölbel and Ackermann [306] and the technology attained a production rate of 11.5 tons (ca. 75 bbl/day) of hydrocarbons per day. In a typical SBCR, synthesis gas enters from the bottom of the reactor and thoroughly mixes with the liquid phase containing catalyst. The reaction takes place on the catalyst surface and the product gas exits from the top, with heavier hydrocarbons being recovered from the bottom using an appropriately sized metal filter. Cooling tubes remove the heat produced by the reaction. The major issue with the slurry phase reactor was product separation from the catalyst. Since some breakthrough of catalyst occurred, activity declined [307]. A problem with conventional SBCRs is scale-up. In most cases, the initial reactor design is solely based on the reactor results from laboratory and/or pilot plant scales. Assumptions made based on preliminary testing of SBCRs at smaller scale may not apply at the industrial scale due to differences in reactor hydrodynamics [232]. However, a recent review by Guettel et al. [155] indicates that adequate models for FTS in SBCRs have been developed that could facilitate scale-up in the future. SBCR technology has been adopted by both industry as well as academia because of simplicity of operation compared to fixed-bed reactors. Deckwer et al. [308] studied the effect of different parameters on reactor performance using the three-phase model; they showed an increase in the overall conversion from 0.79 to 0.97 by increasing reaction temperature from 258 to 290 °C and pressure up to 3 MPa. Increasing H2/CO ratio in the feed continuously decreases the selectivity of C21 + and increases the selectivity of methane [308,309]. Exxon [310] and Sasol [311] have independently developed SBCRs as shown in Fig. 3a and 3b. Extensive work was done to understand the variables affecting the performance of a bubble reactor, allowing insights into churn-turbulent flow [312]; other flow pattern-based models inadequately reflected the reality of SBCR operation. 4.2 Fluidized-bed reactors Sasol has employed circulating fluidized-bed reactors (Fig. 3d) commercially for many years. One drawback is that high temperature operation is required to achieve high productivity. This precludes the use of typical high surface area catalysts, which would otherwise undergo attrition under such harsh conditions; thus, lower surface area, attrition-resistant, catalysts are used. Also, operating at high temperature results in a product distribution having lower α, resulting in a higher fraction of less environmentally benign GHG products (Table 3 ). Other problems include (1) an energy requirement to circulate the catalyst and (2) a pressure drop. The Sasol fixed fluidized-bed reactors have replaced circulating bed reactors. Currently, neither Sasol nor PetroSA plans to deploy any additional plants using this technology. Commercial FTS plants are provided in Table 4 . With the exception of the PetroSA GtL plant in Mossel Bay, all GtL facilities to date are operated by Sasol and Shell. 4.3 Fixed-bed and compact reactors The fixed-bed reactor configuration as a whole though (Fig. 3c) is desirable since it offers high throughput with plug flow behavior, lower maintenance costs, and reduced losses due to attrition and wear. Moreover, they are easily tested at small scale using a single tube. Heat management is an important challenge in fixed bed reactor design. Recently, significant advances have been made in small-scale reactors, especially in light of the current focus by the oil industry on unconventional and renewable feedstocks for syngas generation. Multi-channel fixed bed reactors are much smaller in size, and they are complicated to fabricate [314,315], but they are more mobile, which is useful for reaching stranded resources [316]. The catalytic activity in microchannel reactor can certainly be higher because of the better heat transfer; however, there is also the reactor cost, which is part of capital, and has less impact on economics unless the difference is significantly great. Manufacturing complexity leads to higher specific cost, and it is not completely clear that these reactors, though clearly smaller, are cheaper or more economical. A reason for the unclear path is because the economics are determined by a complicated combination of CO conversion, product selectivities, deactivation rates, regenerability and frequency, as well as time off-line to do it, ultimate catalyst life (replacement time interval), plus reactor and catalyst cost. Generally, cost is calculated by how many barrels can be produced over the lifetime of a catalyst (which accounts for time on stream, conversion/selectivity, and life), rather than the amount of catalyst multiplied by the specific cost. This results in $/bbl numbers for the catalyst can that can range from $1.25 to at least $8.00. The Velocys microchannel reactor [317,318] and Chart’s compact heat-exchanger reactors (CHER) [319] have gained significant attention. Recently, Velocys demonstrated their own technology on a commercial scale in Oklahoma running 2 reactors for more than 5000 h and obtaining renewable fuel credit. Velocys, and Ineratec, show that their microchannel based reactor system achieves superior FTS activity and that it is much more economical than a normal packed-bed reactor, attributing this to a highly efficient method of heat removal from catalyst sites operating at high CO conversion without producing excess methane. The methane selectivity produced by the CHER with catalysts tested was slightly higher, and C5 + selectivity was slightly lower (Table 5 ) than that of a slurry reactor; however, this was attributed in part to differences in catalyst aging. Advantages of Chart's CHER include highly efficient heat removal due to the proximity of the catalyst to aluminum heat exchanger plates. One significant advantage is that small catalyst pellets can be utilized, such that the catalyst can be easily replaced [319]. Research on catalyst development has focused on shortening the length scale of pores within pellets to minimize diffusional problems that negatively impact selectivity [321]. Because H2 diffuses more rapidly than CO within pores, the H2/CO ratio tend to increase deeper within the pore [322], such that catalyst design with shorter pore lengths (with cobalt nanoparticles closer to the pore mouth) benefits selectivity. Shortened pores were achieved on suitably sized catalyst pellets by filling in the interior with alumina; light gas selectivity significantly decreased (Table 6 ), and C5 + selectivity improved [321]. Research efforts including aqueous media as a start-up solvent for Co- or Ru-based FT catalysts offer tuning of FTS product selectivity towards oxygenates; however, catalyst stability remains an issue. Another interesting research area in fixed-bed FT reactors is running at supercritical conditions. Abbaslou et al. [323] recently reviewed the beneficial effect of supercritical media (SCM) on FTS activity and selectivity due to higher heat and mass transfer rates in comparison with conventional gas phase FTS. Fine tuning of the SCM for operation at 220 °C was achieved using a C5/C6 mixture [324]. Switching between the SCM and conventional FTS without the SCM demonstrated significant improvements in CO conversion due in part to the extraction of wax from catalyst pores. However, from a practical standpoint, separation of the SCM from the products adds cost. Structured packing reactors have become attractive in recent years due to their high efficiency for the removal of energy at gas-liquid-solid interfaces. Moreover, structured catalysts improve radial heat transport properties, allowing the application of more active catalysts and the use of larger reactor tube diameters. Different configurations of aluminum (open cross flow, closed cross flow, knitted wire, and form) as depicted in Fig. 4 have been compared for FTS. Despite the fact that these reactors accommodate less catalyst loading on a volume basis compared to traditional packed-bed reactors, they could have 25% higher C5 + productivity due to increased catalyst effectiveness [325]. Finally, monolithic membranes act as a kind of structured packing reactor in which a zeolite membrane is adopted for loading cobalt or iron and used as the catalyst for FTS [326]. The concept of forced-through membrane contactors was introduced by Khassin et al. [327–329] using inorganic membranes with highly dispersed metallic catalysts on macroporous titania-wash coated alumina supports for syngas conversion. The novel membrane based catalyst achieved steady productivity of 100–200 mg/(h cm3 of reactor volume) at 210 °C due to improved mass transfer, as well as a higher density of active component. Higher reaction rates and improved selectivity were achieved with membrane supported metal catalysts for syngas conversion compared to conventional catalysts, where conversion is often limited by the diffusion of reactants into the pores of the catalyst support, as well as by intraparticle diffusion. In general, current commercially demonstrated FT reactors are limited to slurry reactors (Sasol, GtL-F1, and Synfuels China) or multi-tubular fixed bed reactors (Shell, possibly Greyrock Energy). There are a number of technology suppliers who could be considered relatively close, although without actually having a commercial plant in operation today. Compact reactors seem to be a good choice for biomass or remote natural gas feedstocks. 5 Concluding remarks The carbon sources for syngas used in Fischer- Tropsch synthesis depend on the resources available. During World War II, syngas was mainly generated from coal, whereas nowadays, it is mainly produced from natural gas. Considering the current low carbon/CO2 policies to reduce greenhouse emissions, interest in Biomass-to-Liquids as well as Power-to-Liquids has increased. However, these technologies are quite new and additional optimization is needed in order to have commercial plants as in the case of CtL and GtL. Syngas generation followed by gas clean-up takes up 50–65% of the total cost, whereas each step of FT synthesis and product upgrading is estimated to take up to 25–30% of the cost. Syngas cleaning specifications for FTS applications are severe (H2S/COS < 0.01 μLL−1, NH3/HCN < 0.02 μLL−1, alkali and halides < 0.01 μLL−1). Optimization of gasification process conditions (e.g., temperature), as well as development of FTS catalysts more resistant to contaminants like sulfur, can greatly impact the cost analysis. To date, iron and cobalt have been the only commercial catalysts for FTS and the choice mainly depends on the H2/CO ratio of the syngas. Due to its instrinc WGS activity, iron is commonly paired with CtL and BtL, when low H2/CO syngas is available (0.5–1.2), whereas cobalt - possesing low intrinsic WGS activity - is preferred for GtL, as it requires a higher H2/CO ratio (close to 2) to be effective. As the mechanism for FTS is still under scrutiny, and the as potential for greater feedstock and product diversity is high, significantly more research and developmnet is still needed. Furthermore, sheding further light on the electronic tuning of the catalyst surface should pave the way for improving the cost effectiveness of these catalysts. Though the reaction is a century old, there are still many questions regarding the underlying catalyst that need to be answered to further our understanding of this complex process. Optimization of both reactor configuration and process parameters is essential to maximize efficiency and achieve desired product selectivity. Slurry bubble column, multi- tubular trickle-bed, circulating fluidized-bed, and fixed fluidized-bed reactors are well-known reactor designs that have been commercialized for FTS. Recently, in addition to conventional fossil fuels, another current focus by the oil industry is on unconventional and renewable (e.g., biomass) or remote (e.g., stranded natural gas) feedstocks for syngas generation; this has led to the develoment of new compact heat exchange and microchannel reactors. These systems have higher FTS activity and heat removal, although fabrication costs may be higher due to added complexity in the reactor design. coredata.dc:description: This review is divided into three main sections. The first section of this overview examines in detail recent techno-economic analyses on the utilization of biomass as a source of syngas for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS). FTS is a highly localized industry, and depends on the sources of syngas available, the products desired, and the demand for co- production of electricity. Where coal or natural gas coexist in the region where biomass is available, economics may favor producing or blending syngas from multiple resources, making biomass-to-liquids a highly complex scenario. Land use management is essential for sustainable biomass production, if used as the carbon source for FTS. The second section discusses FTS mechanisms, reactions and catalysts. Supposing the catalyst surface energy favors CO hydrogenation to FTS products, the sweet spot of FTS, selectivity will depend on the degree of back- donation from the metal. The degree of electron back-donation from the catalyst surface to both adsorbed CO and vinylic intermediates in part controls the FT synthesis product distribution. When the back-donation is sufficient, chain growth favors longer chained linear hydrocarbons (paraffins, alpha olefins, linear alcohols) suitable for upgrading to diesel, jet fuels, lubricants, and waxes. When back-donation is less significant, monomethyl branched hydrocarbons, internal olefins, and oxygenates (esters, acids and ketones) are elevated. Lastly, active supports are discussed for increasing the termination rate to oxygenates and olefins, as are hybrid catalysts that simultaneously carry out FTS and upgrading, often through secondary reactions. The last section provides an overview of the commercial scale reactor designs including the fixed bed, fluidized bed, and slurry bubble column reactor currently used in the FTS process. Economically, FTS is favored at larger scales; however, new compact reactor designs are coming into play aimed at monetizing highly localized (e.g. biomass) and stranded resources (e.g. natural gas). These types of reactors, involving microchannel and heat exchanger designs, must be highly efficient at managing heat, cost-effective, and mobile in order to exploit non-traditional sources of syngas.
coredata.dc:title: An overview of Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis: XtL processes, catalysts and reactors
